When a small group of living things (a small population) is separated from the main population from which it originated (for example, if it moves over a mountain range or a river, or if it moves to a new island so that it cannot easily return), it often finds itself in a different environment from the one in which it was previously.
This new environment has different resources and competitors, so the new population will need new characteristics or adaptations to be a strong competitor compared to what it needed before.
The original population has not changed at all, they still need the same adaptations.
Over time, as the new population adapts to its new environment, it begins to look less and less like the other population.
Finally, after thousands or even millions of years, the two populations will look so different that they will no longer be considered to belong to the same species.
We call this process "speciation," which simply means the formation of new species. Speciation is an inevitable consequence and an important part of evolution.

Technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, ranging from technological push or technological imperative to a strict sense in which the destiny of humanity is dictated by an underlying logic linked to scientific laws and their manifestation in technologies.

Most interpretations of technological determinism agree on two general ideas: the development of technology itself proceeds beyond the influence of cultural and political factors, and technology has an impact on societies conditioned intrinsically rather than socially.
For example, we could say that the car necessarily leads to the development of roads.
However, a national road network is not economically viable for a handful of cars, which is why new production methods are being developed to reduce the cost of owning a car.
The massive ownership of cars also leads to a greater incidence of accidents on the roads, which leads to the invention of new techniques in the field of health care to treat the physical injuries.

The use of ships for the transport of goods is by far the most efficient way to move large quantities of people and goods across the oceans.

After its adoption by Congress on July 4, a handwritten document signed by President of Congress John Hancock and Secretary Charles Thomson was then sent to a few blocks away, to the printing shop of John Dunlap.

The Moroccan sultan rebuilt the city under the name Daru l-Badya, and it was renamed Casablanca by the Spanish merchants who established trading posts there.

The stirrups are supports for the rider's feet, which hang on either side of the saddle.
They offer greater stability to the user, but they can pose a safety problem: in fact, the user's feet can get stuck in them.
If a rider is thrown from a horse, but has a foot caught in the stirrup, he could be dragged if the horse runs away. To minimise this risk, a number of safety measures can be taken.
First, most riders wear riding boots with a heel and a smooth sole.
Then, some saddles, notably English ones, have safety bars that allow a stirrup to fall off the saddle if it is pulled backwards by a rider who falls.

Europe is a relatively small continent, but it is made up of many independent countries. In normal circumstances, traveling through several countries means having to make several visa applications and passport checks.
The Schengen space, however, works a bit like a single country in this regard.
As long as you stay in this zone, you can generally cross the borders without having to go through passport control.

Violent weather is the generic term for any meteorological phenomenon that can cause damage, serious social disruption, or loss of human life.
Extremely unfavourable weather conditions can occur anywhere in the world, and they can be of several types, depending on the geographical, topographical and atmospheric characteristics.
Violent winds, hail, excessive rainfall and fires are forms and effects of violent weather, just as thunderstorms, tornadoes, marine waterspouts and hurricanes.
Extreme weather phenomena, regional and seasonal, include cold fronts, snowstorms with strong winds, and sandstorms or dust storms.
It is strongly advised to travellers to research the risks of bad weather that may affect their region of destination, knowing that this may have an impact on the itineraries they envisage.

Japanese work culture is more hierarchical and formal than that to which Westerners may be accustomed.
The costumes are traditional work clothes, and employees are called by their family name or their job title.
Harmony in the workplace is crucial, because it puts the emphasis on collective effort rather than on individual achievements.
Workers often need to get approval from their superiors for any decision they make and are supposed to obey their superiors' instructions without question.
